segments.text: OK, I'll say something, and Bill, say something.
All right.
OK, this is Ron Shorn interviewing Bill Hubbard at Boulder, Colorado, on October 21, 1993.
Bill, for the record, would you give your full name?
William Bogle Hubbard.
How do you spell the middle name?
B-O-G-E-L, German name.
And when and where were you born?
Born in Liberty, Texas, November 14, 1940.
How'd you get interested in astronomy?
Well, I received a book from a friend of my father's when I was a kid about planets, which I found very interesting.
And I also spent a number of summers during my childhood in the vicinity of McDonald Observatory and found that quite interesting.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
Rice University.
Why'd you pick Rice?
Because it was inexpensive and it was a good school.
Oh, that was when you still got a full scholarship?
It was a full scholarship.
What was your major?
Physics.
Did you take any astronomy courses in undergrad?
Rice didn't have any astronomy courses when I was an undergrad.
What year did you get your bachelor's?
Why do I remember you at Yerkes Observatory about that period?
Well, it was partly because I was interested in astronomy, but Rice didn't have any astronomy courses.
And I found that a way to fill in my knowledge of astronomy was to work during the summers at observatories.
So I made it a practice to find out about observatories that would accept undergraduates as summer assistants.
And Yerkes had such a program, so that was where I went first.
What year was that?
Yeah, 59 sounds about right.
I know that the way I first found out about this was when I was at McDonald Observatory one summer, and I talked to an astronomer from the University of Chicago.
I believe it was Hiltner, perhaps, who told me about these programs.
What were you doing at McDonald at that time, just visiting?
Just visiting.
Did you do any other observatories in any other summers?
Yes, I worked at McDonald the summer of 60 and the summer of 61.
And also I worked at Kitt Peak the summer of 62, I should add.
Where did you go to grad school?
University of California, Berkeley.
Why did you pick that?
Well, I was trying to find out which programs were good in physics for our graduate research.
Then I decided that I was really more interested in astronomy than in physics.
Since Berkeley had a good program in both, I thought that was a good choice.
And when you began graduate school, what was your major?
Was it physics?
No, it was astronomy.
It was astronomy, okay.
What did you do for your Ph.D. thesis, and who was your advisor?
I decided to go into theory, although I had a fair amount of experience in observing, but I decided that theory was...
more interesting to me at the time.
I started working with Louis Henier on stellar evolution problems.
And he suggested that I work on the problem of thermal conduction by electrons in white dwarf matter, which was, at that time, a poorly understood process.
And I was able to derive a new formalism for that, which was part of my dissertation.
When did you get your PhD?
And where did you go then?
I went to Caltech.
Professor Henye had an arrangement.
Well, he was good friends with William Fowler.
And it was primarily through that interaction that I was able to get a postdoc position with Fowler's group at Caltech.
How long did you stay there?
A little less than two years.
Okay.
So that would be from?
That was from 67 until the summer of 68.
And what did you work on when you were there?
Well, I produced a paper on thermal conduction by electrons in stars, which was basically an expansion of my
dissertation work, which was also in collaboration with Martin Lampe, who did a complementary study.
And we produced tables, which could be used in stellar evolution studies.
I also first started working on planetary problems at that point.
I started working on the interior of Jupiter while I was there.
Why did you get interested in that?
I discovered that the previous calculation of the thermal conduction coefficient in metallic hydrogen
I've forgotten who did that calculation.
It might come from Critchfield.
Critchfield's calculation, I think he was at Los Alamos at the time, it was wrong by orders of magnitude.
And I had just completed this new study, which I believed was applicable to metallic hydrogen as well, and used that to derive the implications for Jupiter based on the new
infrared luminosity measurements of Jupiter, which were just becoming available due to Frank Lowe's work.
What was the difference from what went before?

Well, the big difference was that the thermal conductivity of metallic hydrogen was orders of magnitude lower than Critchfield had estimated, and it clearly indicated that the heat transport in Jupiter could not be carried by thermal conduction by electrons as had previously been estimated.
and it implied that Jupiter had to have a conductive interior structure.
Where did you go after your post-doc?
Well, I had some possibilities from a couple of institutions, but Carlin Smith contacted me.
indicated that the University of Texas would be able to hire me as an assistant professor.
And I was very interested in that position, and I accepted.
So I had my first academic job thanks to Harlan Smith.
How long did you stay at Texas?
Stayed there four years.
I was there from 68 till the summer of 72.
And what were you doing during those four years?
Well, I worked on a variety of problems.
I, of course, taught undergraduate courses a fair amount.
Yes, I taught some graduate courses as well, but I also did research on white dwarfs, oscillating white dwarfs, in collaboration with Brian Warner and Ed Nather, a work I found very stimulating.
But I continued my planetary research.
I worked on interior models of Jovian planets.
And I first started doing some occultation research, because the University of Texas had a very strong stellar occultation program.
Again, Warner and Nader's research and I suggested to them that their expertise might be profitably applied to the occultation of Beta Scorpii by Jupiter, which was in 1971.
And that was a rather large project, which was, I think, fairly successful.
Where did you go after Texas and why?

In 1972, I was contacted by Gerard Kuiper, who was in the process of forming a new academic department to be essentially a part of the Lunar and Planetary Laboratory, which would be a new department of planetary sciences.
At the University of Arizona.
At the University of Arizona, yes.
He was interested in hiring me as one of the initial members of this new academic department.
And I found that offer to be extremely attractive.
So that's why I went to the University of Arizona at that point.
And how long did you stay at Arizona?
Oh, I'm still there.
Oh, that's OK. What department are you in, or institute?
I can't keep them straight.
It is the Department of Planetary Sciences.
The Lunar and Planetary Laboratory was established in 1960 by Kuyper.
And in 1972, he started recruiting the first faculty members for the Department of Planetary Sciences, which was to start basically a graduate program in planetary science.
There was no mechanism for educating planetary scientists at the University of Arizona prior to that point.
For example, Toby Owen, Dale Cruikshank, and Bill Hartman all received degrees from the University of Arizona.
but they did not receive planetary science degrees because there was no such department at the time.
Let me change the subject a little bit now since we've got the chronology.
When you first got started, did you have the feeling that planetary work, since you've done both stellar and planetary work,
that planetary astronomy or planetary science, if you want to call it that, was considered second or third rate by, quote, real, unquote, astronomers?
Oh, yeah, I think that's definitely the case.
I think that stellar astronomy, well, I shouldn't say stellar, I should say astrophysics in general, non-planetary astrophysics, is a much larger field with much greater depth
And much greater distance.
And much greater distance.
And they do, in fact, tend to regard planetary research as a bit of a backwater.
And I think the only reason I got into planetary research was because I found that the problems were very interesting.
And the thing I found lacking in astrophysical work, which I found present in planetary research, is the precision
of measurement which is available in planetary research theories, and observations can be compared on a much more precise level in general.
Better than astrophysical accuracy or cosmological accuracy.
Yes, although I should say that things like pulsars, of course, are counter-examples.
So you think that planetary astronomy still look down a little bit now, even now?
Well, I used to worry about that.
I don't worry about that anymore.
It simply isn't a matter of concern to me.
I think it is a matter of concern primarily to planetary astronomers who are operating in a department of astronomy where they're frequently a minority member of a large astrophysical group.
And they find it very difficult to get colleagues and to promote colleagues and to get resources that they think are commensurate with their efforts.
And I hear this story over and over again.
And that's one of the reasons why I think the Department of Planetary Sciences is such a good thing, because it enables us to essentially support each other.
And it's been spectacularly successful, as I had hoped.
How many departments of planetary science are there in this country?
One.

The University of Arizona is the only one, and I think if you look around now at the number of young people from that department who have received degrees from that department who are now beginning to appear on NASA panels in various positions of leadership, they're all rather young, of course, but they're certainly beginning to have an impact on the field, and I think there's no question that we've been successful.
When did you first cross paths with NASH?
Oh, well, it was probably at the, well, you mean in a formal sense, that is, being a member of a panel or something.
Or getting money from them or something.
Yes.
Well, of course, when I was at Caltech, I talked to people like Bruce Murray and Peter Golrock and so on, who I presume were supported by NASA at the time, but I, of course, was not.
The University of Texas, I was aware that projects like the 107-inch

were being supported by Bill Brunk, and I first met Bill Brunk during one of his many visits to Texas at that time when he was still in the business of supporting observatories or building telescopes.
As a result of some of my Jovian Planet research, I was asked to be a member
of some of the early outer planets planning committees.
I recall one that was chaired by Al Cameron.
I don't remember its precise name.
The name sort of changed from year to year.
Who supported your early Jupiter interior research?
Or, I mean, a theoretician, you didn't need telescopes, but you probably needed some computer money and so forth.
I didn't receive any funding for the first couple of years.
At Texas, it took me a while to get going getting research grants.
Actually, I believe my first grant was from NSF, not from NASA.
I don't recall whether I ever had a NASA grant at the University of Texas.
It's possible that I didn't.
But then at Arizona, is that different?
At Arizona, yes.
At Arizona, I was able to successfully get myself funded from Bill Bronx.
Planetary Astronomy program, and in fact, I've had a Planetary Astronomy grant ever since.
How do you think NASA headquarters has managed planetary research?
This is a personal opinion of yours, but you think they've done it about right?
Have they tried to micromanage?
Do they know what you're doing?
I've found my interactions with NASA to be
basically fairly satisfactory.
I find that the peer review system that has gradually spread throughout the system is probably as good as one could have.

It has its defects, of course, but certainly the Planetary Astronomy Program, which is an example of how things have changed, initially was basically run by Bill Brunk, and the peer review process there was not totally clear to me.
although I thought he managed to do an excellent job of spending his money.
Of course, now there's a very involved peer review program, and I think it does about as well as one can expect it to do.
Where do you think planetary astronomy would be today without the money that NSA has poured into it in the last 30 years?
Oh, I think it would...
it would unquestionably be at the same level that it was in in the 1950s.
I think it would have only a few practitioners, probably most of which would be astrophysicists doing some planetary research as a sideline.
We're at a Division for Planetary Sciences meeting of the American Astronomical Society in the course
26 years ago, since this is the 25th anniversary, there was no DPS, and papers were given such as there were at American Astronomical Society meetings.
The published papers were scattered through all sorts of journals, and in particular a lot of observatory publications.
Now we have Icarus as an official journal and also the Journal for Geophysical Research, Planets.
Do you think these developments have been good?
bad, indifferent, inevitable, your opinion?
You mean the fact that we now have our own journal?
We're separate now, really.
Yes.

Well, I think planetary research is a rather disparate discipline, and what we do here in the DPS is very heavily oriented toward planetary astronomy, which, of course, is only one piece of planetary research.
The field is still...
rather divided across disciplines, and it's definitely an interdisciplinary field.
There is a core of people who show up at DPS meetings, but they don't necessarily represent the full breadth of the field.
Correspondingly, there are a lot of people who show up at AGU meetings who don't always show up at DPS meetings.
So there's still a lot of division in the field.
I think the DPS is a good thing, and it has certainly helped to unify the field.
Well, you're an obvious example of the fact that planetary and non-planetary astronomers talk to each other, as you certainly talk to yourself.
Do you think today that there's much crosstalk between stellar galactic and extragalactic astronomers and planetary ones in your experience?

Well, there's possibly not as much as there should be, but I think there is definitely good communication, and I think the key to making that happen is to have either locations such as Tucson, where all of these people are within a small radius of each other, or else having interdisciplinary workshops or special meetings, topical meetings.
One area that I'm particularly interested in is brown dwarf research, where there's an obvious interface between planetary people and astrophysicists.
Do you think that planetary astronomy is a part of astronomy?
It is, definitely.
I think many of the same instrumental techniques are applicable in both fields and can benefit from some cross-fertilization there.
Since I can't interview Gerard P. Kuiper, I'm asking everyone that knew him, what was he like?
I have to say that I was not an intimate of Gerard Kuiper.
Few were.
Yes.
I interacted with him extensively only during the period between the time that he recruited me at Austin and the time of his death.
And I found him to be a curious mixture of being very advanced and perhaps even ahead of his time in certain concepts, certain planetary concepts, and other concepts were remarkably behind the times.
He, I think, had a vision of what he wanted for planetary astronomy, and I think his
The work that he was doing at the University of Arizona to set up the department and establish the Leonard Planetary Laboratory as a strong institution was certainly in that direction.
So there's no question he was a visionary and both a great scientist and a great builder of institutions.
In terms of his personal characteristics, he was somewhat of a monologuist.
Well, Fred Whipple, who was one of the few people that could call him Gerard, said, and it's on tape, and I guess he was Kuiper's best friend, and Kuiper died in his arms, literally.
And he said Gerard's problem was he couldn't get along with people.
He didn't understand people.
What do you think about that?
I think that's a characteristic that you find among certain very energetic, nervous people, is that they feel compelled to fill the void, and he certainly did that.
You have been at Arizona now for a while.
After Kuiper left the Lunar and Planetary Laboratory, which
you're not directly associated with now, but it's right there.
I am directly associated.
Oh, you are?
That's right.
I'm sorry.
I'm confusing you with somebody else, Mike in particular.
But anyway, when Kuiper left, then who took over?
Charlie Sonnet, right?
Chuck Sonnet.
Chuck Sonnet.
Uh-huh, yeah.
And the laboratory changed directions.
Is that true or not?
That's true.
What direction did it go to, and was that good or bad?
The idea that we all had about the department and the laboratory was that if it was to succeed, it had to be encompassing of the, at least not
perhaps not all, but many of the important areas of planetary science, which would include not only planetary astronomy, but disciplines such as planetary geophysics and planetary geochemistry.
And there already were some planetary geologists there, like Bob Strom, for example.
And so it was agreed among those of us who were the charter members of the department that there should be an effort made to recruit people who were not planetary astronomers,
And I believe that Kuyper was unhappy about some of these decisions.

And I know some of the old-time astronomers who were there at LPL certainly were, because they felt that their discipline, which was basically the basis of LPL's reputation, was being slighted by these new hires.
I think it was the correct decision.
I think it made the place very attractive to students.
The people that were at it were, without exception, very good people who went on to do rather distinguished research.
How long did SONNET last?
Oh, okay.
You want to know about the big fight?
Yeah, supernova explosion.
The big fight, yeah.
Okay.
Well, I have to be a little careful what I say here because many of the principals are still around.
Well, that's like trying to find out just exactly who was behind getting Kuiper fired at Yerkes.
Yes.
Well, let me just say that I'll give you my own opinion about the situation, which is that I believe that planetary astronomy at the University of Arizona was
greatly strengthened by the fact that it had its own telescopes, which the Lunar and Planetary Laboratory controlled.
These were, of course, not first-ranked telescopes by astrophysical standards.
The largest of them was the 154-centimeter telescope, which was built by Kuiper with Bill Brunk's money in the Catalina Mountains.
The rest of the other telescopes were lesser instruments of rather poor quality, but still were controlled by the laboratory, all of these telescopes being in the Catalina Mountains.

The principal issue of the fight was that it was believed by Stewart Observatory that all telescopes should be operated by Stewart Observatory in the interests of efficiency and funding possibilities from NSF and other
organizations.
And this proposal.
And Bart Bach was the director then, right?
No, Ray Wyman was the director.
Although Bart Bach was still around, of course.
Oh, that's right.
After Kuyper's death, Sonnet was faced with the decision of whether to do as the Stewart Observatory astronomer suggested, or whether he should continue as a non-astronomer with the maintenance
in support of these telescopes and the Catalinas.

At the time, many of the observational astronomers in LPL were opposed to having SONNET operate these telescopes, because they felt that as a non-astronomer he was not fully supportive of their programs.
Furthermore, the fact that non-astronomers were being hired was a prime irritant.
And so the fight essentially was between the new guard, which I was a member even though I was hired by Kuiper, and the old guard over the fate of the telescopes and over recruiting policies.
And that struggle led to two outcomes.
One was Chuck's on its resignation.
What year was that?
Do you remember?
It was in 1977.
The result of his resignation was that the telescopes were, in fact, turned over to Stewart Observatory.
And I believe that this is a development which has had both positive and negative results.
The telescopes are still fully available to planetary astronomers and are, as far as I can tell, well maintained.
But at the same time, the fact that the department does not have

These telescopes that it has to keep busy with planetary research has, in my view, led to a subtle but very important pressure to not hire planetary astronomers with the same priority as it might have had in the past.
So I'm very concerned about the fact that this may lead to an eventual decline in the field that we're very strong in.
Who took over?
Who was the department head?
after Kuyper died.
I assume he was the first department head.
Kuyper was actually, I don't think he was the first department head.
The department did not come into existence.
It was not chartered by the Board of Regents until Kuyper, I believe, had already resigned as director of LPL.
Chuck Sonnet was the first head of
of the Planetary Sciences Department, and he was the second director of LPL.
Sonnet resigned, as I said, in 1977, and the laboratory asked me to become director as a compromise in the sense that I was marginally acceptable to both camps.
So I was a reluctant director of the Lunar and Planetary Laboratory and head of
Planetary Sciences for four years during this transitional period in which the department was adjusting to the loss of the telescopes and defining itself further.
Who took over after you managed to get out?
I suggested Laurel Wilkening as my successor because I felt that she would be acceptable also to the various factions in the laboratory, and that proved to be the case.
However, she didn't stay in
as director very long.
I think it was only about a year and a half.
It took over after her.
Gene Levy, who is the current director.
In fact, Levy has been in, I think, probably about as long as Kuyper by now, or getting pretty close to it.
It was revolving.
Dora's there for a while, for a little bit.
Well, it was revolving in the sense that there was some rapid change of leadership, but it was not an unstable situation.
These were orderly transitions.
Let me change the subject.
From your personal viewpoint, what does the public think of when you tell them you're an astronomer?
What's the reaction?
Do they think it's good?
Do they think you're a leech or what?
Well, it's interesting, since you're asking me because I'm at the University of Arizona.
And as you are probably aware, there's been this long, bitter struggle over Mount Graham in Arizona.
And I find that in many cases, people
on the street or people that I meet in various contexts express their annoyance at the way the Mount Graham development has been handled and their annoyance at astronomy.

And I assure them, and this is perhaps the only good thing about the loss of the telescopes, I can assure them that I have nothing whatever to do with this, that it's being handled out of Stewart Observatory.
And I think that what we have to bear in mind
is that as astronomers we don't produce anything that's of palpable economic value, and that we have to make sure that what we do does not alienate the public.
And the benefits that they accrue I think are apparent, but they can be overweighed by things that we do that portray arrogance or lack of concern about what the public thinks about what we're doing.
What's the best piece of work you've done?
Well, I'm pretty proud of the work that I did on Jupiter that I mentioned.
Some of the occultation research that I've carried out I'm rather proud of.
We were among the groups which first detected the Neptunian ring arcs.

and identified them for what they were, and were able to deliver this information prior to the Voyager encounter with Neptune, which I think was sufficiently influential that it enabled Carolyn Porco, for example, to convince the Voyager 2 team to point the cameras in the right place to detect these ring arcs.
One little thing I think that it's probably worth mentioning
connection with Gerard Kuiper is that in 1981, Harold Reitzema, Dave Tholen, Larry Lebowski, and I observed using the former LPL telescopes in the Catalinas.
This was, of course, after the telescopes had been turned over to Stuart, but we were using Kuiper's telescope.
Harold Reitzema and I were on the 61-inch
And we detected a third Neptunian ring, which is now called, not ring, satellite, which was subsequently named Larissa.
And I felt a great satisfaction in finding a new satellite of Neptune.
Of course, Kuiper discovered Nereid, the second satellite.
But I felt great satisfaction in detecting this new satellite with Kuiper's telescope.
Do you ever have any dead ends, misfires, things you wish you would not have gotten into?
Well, I certainly didn't enjoy being head of the department and director of Lunar and Planetary Laboratory, and I often wonder what would have happened if I'd turned that down.
Probably nothing bad would have happened to me.
I'm not sure about the laboratory.
Well, you are in this situation.
Somebody that looks pretty sharp comes up and says, gee, I want to be a planetary astronomer right now.
We're obviously at the start of another big funding crunch like happened in 73 and 81.
What do you tell the students?
Yes, no, or what?
I think students have to have a pretty tough attitude these days.
The analogy that unfortunately comes to mind is baby tortoises.
They hatch out at a great rate, but most of them perish, and that may be the situation we're in right now with tortoises.
planetary scientists and also with astronomers, only the very best are going to succeed and survive in the long term doing what they currently plan to do.
Well, I guess come to think of it, it's just like astronomy in general before the space age, before Sputnik.
I mean, you know, there just aren't a whole lot of jobs.
None of the principles are alive, I believe, so I just have to ask people.
At the turn of the century, planetary astronomy was a respectable part of astronomy.
Henry Norris Russell did work on the Venus atmosphere.
By the end of World War II, it was basically dead.
What killed it, or who killed it?
I don't think it was anybody's decision to kill it.
I don't think there was an attempt to do that by anybody.
I think that it was...
the lack of tools for precise work, and also the lack of tools for interesting new discoveries, which basically sent the field into a period of suspended animation for all that period of time.
Well, the point was, of course, there was essentially no infrared.
And that's where the spectral features are of interest, most of them.
And photometry was not very good.
Well, radar astronomy.
Radio, planetary radio astronomy, one can go on and on.
But basically, the very limited spectrum and the very limited resolution which was available were the things that made planetary astronomy not able to progress very well.
Gerard de Vaucouleur had an emphatic two-word answer to that question.
Percival Lowell.
Do you think that had an effect as well?
You mean a negative influence on planetary astronomy?
No, I don't think so.
I think Percival Lowell deserves a lot of credit.
I mean, after all, the planet Pluto was discovered as a result of his investment of time and money.

Do you think that the fact that we haven't been able to find any evidence of life anywhere in the solar system so far, in particular on Mars, has had a depressing effect on public interest and funding?

I think as I study the field more and as I learn more about modern concepts of chaos and applications of that theory to biology and to planetary systems, the more I realize that the borderline between life and non-life is very fuzzy indeed.
And if you look through the solar system, you'll find many examples of survival of the fittest, for example, as well as systems which are in
very unlikely states, highly organized, unlikely states.
And I think that we have to be careful about what we mean by life.
And I think it's not at all excluded that we'll discover life in some fashion in the solar system.
Just looking at, I mean, we've learned a lot about the planets and satellites and so forth in the last 30 years.
What do you think is the most important thing?
And I'll give you my particular one, just to give you an example, is that we used to think you had gas giants and then rocks.
And now we've found there's this whole other kind of planet, namely the icy ones, that no one ever thought of before.
That's my candidate.
What's yours?
Most important discovery in planetary science.
Or change of thinking, either one or another one.
I think the most important change in thinking that we have, in my view, which I think is mirrored also in astrophysics,
is the discovery that we're in a dynamic situation, that we live in a system which is evolving on all kinds of time scales and spatial scales in a very complex manner.
And it's not a quiescent clockwork system which is frozen into some sort of state, which it's been in for eons.
So it's not the Laplace-Lagrange universe that once was.
That's right.
There's been a lot of attention lately to things like making planetary astronomy practical.
A lot of publicity of killer asteroids and comets, the ozone layer depletion, global warming.
Do you think that's been overdone, or do you think that it's good science, and so what if it's popular?
Let's get the money and work on it.
My visceral reaction is that it's kind of nauseating.
I don't like self-serving hype.
I think there's a lot of that, and I think the so-called killer asteroid concept is definitely in that category.
I spend a lot of time on this subject with my undergraduate classes because it inevitably comes up, and what I tell them is that one's risks of being killed

within the next year, say, can be calculated quantitatively from a variety of threats, and certainly the biggest threat is a drunk driver, and killer asteroids are way down the list, as are many of the other threats that you've mentioned.
Science in general has a bad name, you know, make nuclear weapons and everything, and
for some reason astronomers, including planetary astronomers, seem to have escaped that.
Do you think that's true?
Well, they might have escaped that prior to Mount Graham.
I think that problems like Mount Graham unfortunately tend to lump us in the same category as the other scientific efforts which are considered to be bad for humanity.
But I think
Science doesn't have any particular moral orientation, and it can be applied in a variety of ways, some of which are beneficial and some aren't.

Well, in general, but also in particular on the Mount Graham issue, because you're in the crossfire whether you're actually part of it or not, do you think astronomers in general and planetary scientists in particular have done as good a job as they could have in selling themselves to the public?
As I say, we have to bear in mind that what we produce is of no direct benefit to humanity in the sense that it does not have obvious economic value.
I think attempts to link it to obvious economic value are not appropriate.
I think that what we have successfully done, what we should continue to do, is to amaze, thrill, inspire people

the public with our discoveries and as long as we do a good job of that i think we're okay you think planetary science is kind of mined out i mean you think all the big things have been found all the spectacular stuff or no no not at all i think what's the direction we're moving in is that planetary science is moving in the direction of planetary geophysics uh within c2

measurements or with precise remote measurements in various ways, we were able to achieve precision of measurement and wealth of detail of measurement which are comparable to those which are now available to geophysicists.
So what we have basically is an array of Earths, of objects which are as complex and about which we'll have the same sort of detailed knowledge that we have about the Earth.
And of course, there are scores of such objects.
So I think we're going to enter a whole new era in the next century.
Here's a leading question.
But were you surprised when it became obvious that little icy satellites of other planets really had a history, and they just didn't form and sit there forever?
Were you surprised at that?
No.
I mean, this is part of what I mentioned before, which is, I think, that we have now learned that the solar system is a system which is evolving in a very complex manner, even at present.
And certainly, some of the outer planet satellites are much more interesting than the moon.
The moon turns out to be a rather dull place in comparison, but in my view, it's still a very interesting place as well.
I'd say keep in touch with reality by having to teach undergrads.
Well, is enrollment up, down, interest up, down over the last 10 or 20 years?
Or what's the situation at Arizona, at least?
I find that we get a lot of interest from undergraduates.
They're not as well prepared in many cases as one would like.
But I think interest is as high as ever.
One more thing.

My personal opinion is that planetary astronomy starts with the Venus tablets from the dynasty of Hammurabi when they give observations of when Venus was first visible in the west after sunset and last visible in the east before sunrise and so forth.
There are other people that claim that planetary astronomy only began
when Galileo first pointed his telescope at, say, Jupiter and Venus.
When do you think planetary astronomy began?
Planetary astronomy was the start of astronomy.
The first things that were understood in any sense were the planets.
And so that dates back basically to the first naked eye observations of moving objects in the sky, which were planets.
So definitely I agree with you.
